The analysis which you have shown is of Haryana Farmers or your Chacha's chart. This doesn't represent entire India. Farmers of Punjab, Haryana and western UP are very rich. If farmer  or any individual become rich and flow of money to him/her is good, he/she always demand for more, efforts increases for more money but return stagnate. This is called rat-race trap. When the individual or family, or a region or a country is trapped in this rat-race, they lost innovation. When innovation is lost, it is difficult to find the solution of the problem. I was expecting form your video that how farmer should improve their farming (but that require lot of time and money to do such deep-dive research). How to increase the productivity? how to retain the moisture of the soil, crop rotation, use of scientific methods? Deserts to be converted in to rich fertile farm lands, water conservation techniques. Hence it should look like video is created after having deep dive research done by hard-core professional (not like failed IAS aspirants). If you still need to compare, then compare apple-to-apple not apple-to-orange.  If you use apple-to-orange comparison then people will realize that you don't have knowledge of taste. If the new generation with AI equipped knowledge watches your video after 15 years, they will see that people in foreign countries compare the situation of countries such as India in an unscientific manner. Science and economy should be synced properly to find the solution of the problem. 
Now as a farmer: -  The first option is for farmers to try to sell at local markets, usually very small farmers. The second option is for slightly larger farmers to sell in the APMC mandi, and the third option is through MSP. The problem is APMC mandi, where the inside traders/agents have upper hand and hence because  of these agents farmers are not earning based on their efforts. APMC mandi need to be modernize like Amazon and Flipkart. In APMC mandi buyers and sellers are being connected by inside traders/agent. The only difference between Amazon and Flipkart is that their process are transparent and scientifically framed, while the APMC is not transparent and process are raw and need a lot of improvement. Now since APMC is not transparent, the farmers moved to Govt, and govt decided that farmer should  sell to them under MSP. But the limitation of MSP is that only 23 crops are covered (MSP doesn't cover the broad range of crops), hence farmers are not benefited much by MSP. Thee issue is in APMC mandi. However this is my thought and may be most of the citizens may agree to me.

Fixed daily wages for farming to the farmers under MGNREGA, Rs 700 a day with 200 days of guaranteed employment a year.[3]
Government to ensure at least 50% profit over their overall cost of production.[4]
Legal guarantee of minimum support price (MSP) for all the crops
Implement the recommendations of the MS Swaminathan committee on agriculture[5]
Justice for Lakhimpur Kheri violence[6]
Urge the government to fulfill its promise to double farmers' incomes, highlighting the surge in cultivation costs over recent years and the stagnation of incomes, which has rendered farming a loss-making enterprise.[4]
Call for the withdrawal of legal cases filed against protesters during the previous agitation in 2020-21.[4]

Sharad marathe naukri karke kisanon ka problem kaise samajh liye. Issi tarah modi govt main bahut aise executives jo govt main bade bade post main rahkar apne tarike se india farming aur other sectors ka solution corporate house ko suite karne wale kale kanoon banaye. PM ke salahkar Mr.Oberai bolte hain Sambidhan ko badalne chahiye. Sambidhan likhna jaise kisi kitaab likhni jaisi hai Vivek Oberoi sochte hain. Pichhle 10 saal se jitne bhi kanoon pass hue hain ye sab aloktantrik. Kya kiya jaye yahan to oposition apna prasna karne ki adhikar nahin. Bahut logon ko ED, CBI, POLICE aur income tax ke dabab se farji case bana diya jata hai. Ye hamare desh main monopoly ho rahi hai. Might is right. Iss sarkar ne opposition ka nak main dum kar rakha hai to aam insaan aur kisan ki kya chalegi.

MSP is a great concept, necessary for supporting farmers BUT there are many things which it almost seemed Dhruv didn't touch on purpose: 
1. Economic viability of MSP for all crops in all states at all levels.
2. The fact that private traders rarely buy at MSP and it is the government which is forced to buy crops at higher than reasonable rates. This very MSP is far more expensive than the international rate, so all of the crops which the government buys become a dead weight.
3. MSP should be promoted among private traders, and it's enforcement for the same should be strengthened. Forcing the govt to buy more and more crops is simply unviable (refer 2).

Dear Dhruv Rathee,

I've been a follower of your work for the past 5-6 years, watching nearly all your videos and eagerly sharing them with my family. Your content has always stood out to me for its informative and fact-based approach. I even encourage my children to watch your channel and quiz them on the videos to ensure they're learning alongside me. Your impact on us has been significant, and we value the knowledge you've shared over the years.

However, I've noticed a shift in your content over the past year. It seems like you've strayed from your core focus of knowledge-sharing and instead embarked on what appears to be a mission to oppose the government. Let me clarify that I'm not affiliated with any political party, but I can't help but feel concerned about this apparent agenda in your recent videos. While I acknowledge the challenges our country faces, I believe there have been positive developments as well, which seem overlooked in your content.

You mentioned in your videos that you've covered positive aspects too, but it feels like the ratio of positive to negative coverage is heavily skewed. This deviation from your usual balanced approach is disheartening for your genuine followers like me. Your content now feels more like activism rather than informative discourse. On one hand, you highlight how the media is under government control, yet on the other, you seem to selectively present facts that oppose the government, neglecting instances of good governance.

As someone who genuinely wishes the best for you, I urge you to remain neutral and provide unbiased viewpoints. We long to see the original Dhruv Rathee who enlightened us with knowledge and information and whose tagline was тАЬExplainers that InspireтАЭ, not one on a mission to constantly oppose the government. This shift in your content has generated negativity and could tarnish your image. I'm not sure if this message will reach you, but I felt compelled to share my concerns.

Thanks

Presently he is popular and powerful because of which he is winning. He has delivered no development. Mistreated the states by holding their money from centre.
He is no more than fancy dress and cutouts. Can't be trusted with votes. Mere scare crow who may last for few more years and he is a nonconsequencial figure. 

In Karnataka Modi has been losing (26/28to 65/135) despite the state being a Hindutva/BJP bastion even before his arrival in national politics. Trust deficit is the key factor. It is BJP Vs BJP. 

In Tamil Nadu His master's voice (Annamalai) is filling media while Modi has just flashed Katchateevu which at this point is untimely and nonconsequencial. 

Modi plays what he is best at, Electioneering - Roadshow/ Showering with petals/ Podium speech/ Fancy dress/ Cutouts. Modi Modi Modi ............. Sometimes it pays and many times it doesn't. He doesn't seem to care. 

For BJP hatrick for Modi is the only goal. Electoral Bonds, Proportional representation for OBC, Manipur violence. These are too trivial !

Dude,  I saw your dictator video and I thought you're  a man of reason. 

But this is utter crap, telling msp is opposite of mrp. 

So should government give minimum support guarantee  to all the products and services in the market? 

Take the emotions out and see Farming as a business, it is the duty of the business to run it profitably.  If you can't run it profitable then go do a different business as simple as that. 

On your point on farmers selling products lower than  your calculated MSP logical conclusion is simple that product is not worth the cost.

By saying you will buy all products at msp you're messing with the markets free demand and supply. 

You can support the  sector growth rather by putting input tarrifs on those products or give input credits like cheaper electricity, cheaper water, lower rate of interest etc.  Which can help to bring the cost of production down. 

I'm with you on how the bill got passed in Raja Sabha should be condemned and in my view it is unconstitutional 

But don't just spread negativity   on a policy just because it comes from a party / a person you're not supportive of.

Good points made - couple of things to look into for me (don't have sufficient knowledge to draw conclusions):

1. Comparison with companies including all costs as expenses - they include all costs and set a pricing to cover them + profits, but no one is committing to buy their goods/services in general - they bear the risk of demand. Is it fair to compare?

2. Is (A2+FL) + 50% not enough to cover other costs? Average profit margins for farming in mature markets are around 10%-15% (11% in US) - does 50% on top of A2+FL not provide enough buffer to cover remaining costs and then make a comparable margin? In fact in the excel screenshot at 19:40, costs excl. land rental are 39,500 - so adding 50% on top gives me ~20k profit, which covers land costs and give a 6%-7% margin (too low - but this analysis would help build a better picture and then maybe the right no. is not 50 but 75) 

3. In proposed scenario, if we cover all costs and then add 50% on top, we eliminate most of the business risk from farming - is it then fair to then also offer the upside? Shouldn't the govt. capture this upside in situations where market prices are higher - which helps build a pool of money to fund MSP during periods where market prices are low?

Again - I don't have the answers but to me this perspective seems to be missing in the narrative.

My father is a farmer. He works hard day night but input in growing crops is high and output we get is so less. The cost of water, electricity, diesel, seeds ,equipments, labour and fertilizers is so much that we can barely save any money after selling the crop... Only basic household needs are met and the expenses start for next crop. 
Even vegetables we grow and sell them in Sabjimandi.. We get very less price like тВ╣5/kg while the vendors and shopkeepers buy that and sell it for even 40-60 rupees. This is the plight of  Indian farmers and yet government is not ready to listen to these hardworking people.

Note: Government has announced MSP for Milling Copra at тВ╣ 11160/- per quintal and for Ball Copra at

тВ╣12000.00 per quintal for 2024 season.

To realize the objectives of MSP Policy, Government extends price support for paddy and wheat through the Food Corporation of India (FCI) and State Agencies. Under this policy food grains offered by farmers within the stipulated period & conforming to the specifications prescribed by Government are purchased at MSP by the State Government agencies and FCI for Central Pool. Additionally, Oilseeds, pulses and copra of Fair Average Quality (FAQ) are procured from registered farmers under Price Support Scheme under Umbrella Scheme of PM-AASHA, as per its guidelines at MSP in consultation with the concerned State Governments, when market price of these produce fall below the MSP. Cotton and Jute are also procured by Government at MSP through Cotton Corporation of India (CCI) and Jute Corporation of India (JCI), respectively. GovernmentтАЩs price policy is to ensure remunerative prices to farmers by offering to procure their produce at MSP. However, farmers are free to sell their produce to the Government procurement agencies at MSP or in the open market, whichever is advantageous to them.

The procurement of foodgrain has increased from 761.40 lakh metric tonnes in 2014-15 to 1062.69 lakh metric tonnes in 2022-23, benefitting more than 1.6 crore farmers. The expenditure incurred (at MSP values) on procurement of foodgrains increased from 1.06 lakh crores to 2.28 lakh crores, during the same period.

 

This information was given by the Union Minister of Agriculture and FarmersтАЩ

Very knowledgeable and indepth video on MSP and how govt is regulating the market around some big players. But taking into account that if MSP is implemented which state farmers are most benefited. Is it like all farmers around the country will have same price for same type of crops. The kind of protest that happened at Delhi NCR was not like farmers protest. Farmers came on their tractors, four wheeler cars to block the roads and create pressure on govt. If these farmers are capable of having four wheelers and number of tractors why they need the MSP support. They would have sufficient area of land if they themselves sell some of their crops in the market they will incur all their expenses to grow that crops. MSP should be the support to those farmers only who has deficit amount of land on which 2-3 crops can be grown at a time and they hardly meet their daily livelihoods.
In India, there are many such regions where poor farmers donтАЩt even have the money to afford rental tractors or have direct contact with central govt to sell their crops and on the other hand there are farmers who have 3-4 tractors to cultivate the land and always demand govt to take the crops on MSP and every time with an increased value.
Major part of the budget will always go to a certain group of farmers who have larger land and huge amount of crops can be grown on which govt provide high MSP. And all small farmers will either get little or nothing for their crops.
MSP might create a border between large farmers who have larger land area and the farmers who have small land area.

If a farmer is from a poor background, he needs to do hard work just like a middle class man does. Why this extra leverage? If so then every indian should get benefits from government. If one is farmer then considering it as a downside is what I feel like playing a victim card which fake feminists do. An average indian family (middle class family) teacher their children to study, work hard and stand on by himself. This fugitive kind of demand for A2+FL+C2тАжlol. Every Indian should demand then, for no taxes on lands, no municipal taxes. 


And if we are talking about home labour, who will enjoy the income the farmer earned? The family. Then why this home labour concept? 
Lol. Playing victim card because the person is a farmer, fugitive behaviour it is. They need 1.5 times more MSPтАжwhat about the middle class families who work hard to earn money. This will definitely rise the price of crops and vegetables. A middle class family will like to buy a kg of onion for Rs 100/- always? Or potato for Rs 80/kg? 

ItтАЩs true that farmers do labour and hard work and even get in debt but giving so leverage isnтАЩt fair. What about equality then? Government should allow or say should fix a margin that this crop wonтАЩt be sold below that price tag so no one will be buying onion for Rs 2/kg. Also, the A2, FL and C2 can vary from state to state. Different climate conditions, different types of soil, water conditions, environment conditions matters. 
What government should do is that, for example if a farmer has to invest suppose 10 rupees to grow one kg onion, government should margin that or a bit more. No one will able to below 10 or 12 rupees. That will be fair and I guess wonтАЩt affect our economy that much

This Indian farm protest is a delusional attempt by some folks. I will cite an example, outside India - a vegetable imported from India costs 2-3 times than those imported from China or Malaysia. For example, vegetable / fruit will cost you 5-6 dollars, when the same fruit from China will cost you 2.25 dollars or from Malaysia - 3.45 (actual prices).

So, it is either that Indian fruits and vegetables are made of something special (I wouldn't say gold), or that their price setting does not consider supply-demand parameters... I personally never buy anything imported from India precisely for this reason, it is abnormally priced, fruits and vegetable pricing is simply unrealistic. How can Indians charge 6 dollars for vegetables that are about 2-3 times cheaper from China? Let us all wake up - market forces to determine pricing, government just regulates inflation and should not have any role in price setting.

тЭдтЭд

The current MSP system is shitty. 
The producer does not have the freedom to sell it anywhere else other than mandi. The middle man is taking benefit of this and they are creating a cartel and they are buying produce at much lesser than MSP. Or else they are not buying. This makes farmers have no other choice but sell their produce at dirt cheap price. And that is why no new farmers are being created and no advancement in farming technology is happening like we can see in other sectors in the country.

So it can be said that if only MSP is guaranteed and farmers are allowed to sell anywhere they want within the country, then that would help. That would need to change the MSP law.
But adding an MSP guarantee to all kinds of crops, vegetables and fruits won't be too much of a burden to the Government? After all this money will be extracted from the middle class salaried employees like us.
And if you put MSP on selected products then who will protect the rights of farmers who are producing other produce?
Also there is always a risk of Businesses importing farm food products from outside of the country if they get the produce at a lesser price. That will impact the local produce and local farmers as their products will be less or unsold. We can say that in that case the government can impose a restriction that Business should buy from local farmers only. But then there are chances that the farmers will form cartels and increase their prices as they now know that the buyers do not have any other choice other than buying it from them. 
This is a vicious cycle. 
I think we should scrape the MSP system and think of something else which is relevant to current times.
Have you thought why MSP benefits are only helping farmers of Punjab and Haryana?
MSP system is introduced during the green revolution. 
Have you thought why the green revolution predominantly happened in Punjab and Haryana?
Why rice, a water demanding crop was promoted to be grown in Punjab and Haryana whereas as the best place for rice production is Eastern India? I mean wheat is fine but rice, that also in up north ignoring the water logged fields of Bengal and Assam!
I think instead of the MSP, Government should empower farmers. Create infrastructure for farmers like cold storage warehouses, Facilities for seed culture, educate farmers with latest sustainable and environment friendly farming technology and many many more.
The government can even put some sort of security like pension and health policies for people who are working in farms to promote and motivate farming.
This communist policy of making life of people better artificially by enforcing laws instead of address the core of the issue will not work for long. These policies are a temporary patch so that you can walk little more distance. If your idea is reach your destination by keep putting patches every now and then then you will reach your destination but by the time you reach, it would be very late and pathetic.
So if you want to actually improve the condition of the farmers, you will have to go to the root and take steps locally and not by just creating a policy which you wish will fit for all just like this MSP. MSP can be a temporary arrangement to buy time but cannot be a permanent solution.

See the issue is not the farming or economic viability.  People who believe in outdated ideology mislead farmers. In the era of globalization, our farmers should have access to the world market. P.V Narasimha Rao ji reformed industrial sector and it led to economic boom. Now it is time to reform farming sector. Earlier farm-laws would have done that as Government tried to delink the farmers from Mandi/market yard that form syndicate & suppress prices. Now wherever you go in USA or UK stores except Indian stores , it is the Chinese & Thailand rice.  Indian Agro exports are very limited. If our fake farm leader had allowed the earlier farming reform laws. farmers would have gotten good price for their produce as it becomes very competitive. Instead, market yard lobbies with clueless politicians created fear in farmers and forced the government to withdraw the farm law.  Government can't give MSP for each produce in advance as it depends on supply and demand. Say if there was 200% supply of rice that can't be exported due to revoked farm law by any buyer, what should the government do? Procure, store and trash? The solution is to leave it to market forces and government should see that buyers don't become syndicate & cause losses to farmers

As a son of a farmer I can say everything shown in the video is correct . My Father has more than 3 acre so we don't always suffer loss, the reason why I said loss is because there are some times when the crop is destroyed or catches a disease or something like that ( obviously there is crop insurance but just like other government schemes, it's not easily accessible  ). Actually we have more than 30 acre farm land and due to that even if we suffer loss in one crop then we have another crop that can make things balanced but it's not true for small farmers as they can't have multiple crops. We are living as a somewhat in middle class and that's only possible because of a small business running together. To be honest if we didn't had that business and extremely laborious father then I might not be writing this comment or at least not in English language ( in todays time the expenses of study, daily needs, medical bills, taxes and other stuff are really high ).

I watched both right and left wing videos on this topic, they are talking about political angle, but it's matter is mostly of economic angle, 
Main problem is intermediary between farmers and consumers, farmers don't sell directly to consumers nor consumers directly buy from farmers, so the main supply is done by intermediaries, the price of some crops are less if they have been bought from Russia, Ukraine and other countries, our farmers use outdated techniques of farming so their production cost is high, if the imported product is of less value then demand for domestic things falls, that is also simple economics, i think dhruv forgot that economic knowledge, 
According to me, the solution for this might be consumers should try to buy directly from farmers as much as possible, and farmers should also set up some kind of place where they can do retailing, orelse we will be just fighting for and against of political party but main problem will not be addressed

Your analysis is superb.

When a company takes all of these costs into consideration, then it are the stakeholders in the company who take care of the cost and not the government, so your comparison does not fit here. Next, the government is already buying crops at the required MSP, which is being increased each year. You cannot expect every private entity to buy at that same price as well. Why would a middle class person, pay for a fruit which is seasonal, at THE MSP when it is available for a cheaper price, your logic would indicate only farmers getting richer and middle class getting poorer and burdened. Next, the government tried to help them by eliminating middle men, who used to absorb their income, but your rich farmers of Punjab and Haryana, who are the richest and the only ones protesting, and are acciusotemed to the mandi system, are happily doing protests. This is where farmers from Punjab and Haryana spoilt it for all farmers in India. Most of these people are not even poor and some of them are not even farmers, but Khalistan's. I am sure your videos fool half of your gallant leftist crowd but won't fool other citizens.
Lastly, the government needs to ensure the needs of all classes, and if it was according to you and your rich farmers dearest, all the budget was to be going to the farmers. Kindly, be more mindful then spreading false propaganda.

Addressing Challenges Faced by Persons with Disabilities: A Comprehensive Approach

Accessibility Infrastructure:

Issue: Inadequate accessibility infrastructure in public spaces, transportation, and buildings.

Solution: Government initiatives to enforce accessibility standards, retrofit existing infrastructure, and incentivize private sector involvement.

Public Cooperation: Raising awareness and advocating for accessible design principles in community projects and urban planning.

Education and Employment:

Issue: Limited access to quality education and employment opportunities.

Solution: Government-funded special education programs, vocational training, and inclusive hiring policies.

Public Cooperation: Encouraging inclusive practices in schools and workplaces, offering mentorship and support networks.

Healthcare Services:

Issue: Inadequate healthcare services tailored to the needs of persons with disabilities.

Solution: Establishing specialized healthcare facilities, training healthcare professionals in disability-inclusive care, and subsidizing medical expenses.

Public Cooperation: Supporting community health initiatives, advocating for accessible healthcare services, and promoting disability awareness in medical training.

Social Stigma and Discrimination:

Issue: Persistent social stigma and discrimination against persons with disabilities.

Solution: Government-led awareness campaigns, anti-discrimination laws, and promotion of inclusive cultural representations.
Public Cooperation: Challenging stereotypes, fostering empathy, and creating inclusive social environments through community engagement and education.

Legal Rights and Accessibility Policies:

Issue: Limited awareness and enforcement of disability rights and accessibility policies.

Solution: Strengthening legal frameworks, ensuring enforcement mechanisms, and promoting accessibility audits.

Public Cooperation: Advocating for policy reforms, participating in accessibility audits, and reporting violations.

Technology and Innovation:

Issue: Lack of access to assistive technologies and inclusive digital platforms.

Solution: Government funding for research and development of assistive technologies, tax incentives for inclusive tech companies, and promoting digital accessibility standards.

Public Cooperation: Supporting open-source initiatives, providing feedback on accessibility features, and advocating for universal design principles in technology.

Transportation and Mobility:

Issue: Limited accessible transportation options and infrastructure.

Solution: Investing in accessible public transportation, subsidizing mobility aids, and implementing inclusive urban planning.

Public Cooperation: Prioritizing accessibility in transportation policies, advocating for barrier-free infrastructure, and offering support to persons with disabilities during travel.

Emergency Preparedness and Response:

Issue: Neglect of the specific needs of persons with disabilities in emergency situations.

Solution: Developing inclusive emergency response plans, training first responders in disability awareness, and providing accessible emergency shelters.

Public Cooperation: Participating in disaster preparedness drills, advocating for disability-inclusive emergency protocols, and offering assistance to vulnerable communities during crises.

By addressing these key areas through collaborative efforts between governments, communities, and individuals, India can create a more inclusive society where persons with disabilities can thrive and contribute to the nation's development.

Firstly, I must applaud you for your insightful analysis of the prevalent issues in developing countries. I am currently watching your video from Pakistan ЁЯЗ╡ЁЯЗ░ and come from a family of farmers. We primarily grow crops such as tobacco, wheat, maize, and grass for animal feed. I would like to bring to your attention that we sell tobacco at extremely low prices, while tobacco companies make huge profits from the price at which we sell per kg of tobacco to them. For instance, this year in Pakistan, the price of tobacco is approximately PKR 750, whereas a packet of cigarettes costs around PKR 650, and one 2-leap of tobacco is used in making that one packet of cigarettes, which is approximately 30 to 40 grams. This trend is evident in the prices of other crops as well. It is disheartening to see how governments and corporate companies exploit poor farmers worldwide. However, I have immense respect for your work and the attention you bring to such vital issues ЁЯе░ЁЯе░.

What actually needed is sufficient infra to store and distribute agricultural commodities. If the government can give тАЬguaranteeтАЭ for the same, there will not be any requirement of MSP and the agricultural produce will ultimately become cheaper. Till the government cannot provide sufficient storage and distribution infra, the government has to provide MSP and bear тАЬa littleтАЭ additional cost.

As of now, no government tried to solve the deep-rooted problem of scarcity of storage and distribution network. Instead, the political parties used the scarcity for their vote bank. The farmers need to unite and demand for infra for long term solution.

Hi Dhruv, this is an awesome video. Just one thing that you should have added more punch to the point that the govt never buys the entire produce and therefore the actual cost of MSP implementation can be just 21000 cr or even zero. MSP is a safety net and will trigger when prices crash in the open market. Also if govt is buying at MSP then private players will have to buy above MSP else farmers will simply go to Mandi and sell it. The catch is that if mandi denies to buy from farmers on account of quality (Grain size , moisture etc...) or any other excuse which is expected to happen then the mechanism for redressal has to be strong.

FARMERS MATTERS ЁЯЗоЁЯЗ│тЭд

It is not correct to say that the middlemen get the profit equal to the  difference between Rs 21 and Rs 250. There are costs such as transport, storage, labour, rent etc. as well as wastes and pilferage. Also sometimes, middlemen have to sell at lower price than purchase price. There are many agencies in supply chain such as distributor, wholesaler, retailer etc. So the entire margin is not to one entity. There is a considerable tax element too. Projecting this will make it a balanced representation. Having said this, the fact remains that the farmers should get a fair and well deserved minimum price not only to sustain but also have an opportunity to prosper

FARMERS' PROTEST - A Path Forward

The farmer is back on the road, leaving the common Indian both troubled and confused. Those on tractor trolleys, enjoying 5-star arrangements at the protest site, don't fit the image of impoverished farmers. Yet, the grim reality persists with daily reports of farmer suicides. In 2023 alone, over 20,000 farmers took their lives.

But what's the truth behind it all? While farmer leaders advocate for MSP as the ultimate remedy, government experts warn of its budgetary repercussions. So, where lies the truth?

The truth, it seems, eludes us all.

Before uncovering the whole truth, let's delve into some basic agricultural economics.

Natural calamities play a pivotal role in agriculture. Despite a farmer's toil тАУ plowing, seeding, fertilizing, and watering тАУ sudden hailstorms, locust invasions, or stray animals can decimate entire crops. While these disasters trouble farmers, most don't contemplate suicide, as crop insurance and government aid provide some relief. When yields dwindle, crop prices surge, offering some solace.

However, the real tragedy unfolds when nature bestows abundance. Ironically, the more bountiful the harvest, the higher the suicide rates.

In bumper crop years, traders exploit small farmers' inability to store surplus produce, driving prices to rock bottom. While larger farmers navigate through, smaller ones тАУ burdened with loans, future seed purchases, and household expenses тАУ find themselves ensnared. Sometimes, plummeting prices fail to cover harvesting costs, compelling farmers to abandon their crops.

These are the farmers, paradoxically, driven to suicide by a prosperous harvest.

But there's a solution to this seemingly intractable problem.

Understanding the problem's essence is crucial to finding a solution. Fundamentally, when crops flourish, consumer demand remains constant, yet oversupply and inadequate storage means farmers, particularly small ones, require immediate funds. Exploiting this vulnerability, traders depress prices significantly. That's the crux of it.

Once we identify the problem, the solution isn't as daunting.

Enter the FARMER Survival LAW (FSL) тАУ akin to a тАШMinimum WageтАЩ law.

While тАШMinimum WageтАЩ laws don't burden governments financially, they safeguard impoverished workers effectively.

So, what's FSL?

The government mandates a Minimum Support Price (MSP) for each crop, prohibiting any entity from purchasing below this threshold. FSL's success hinges on effective implementation.

Let's illustrate with an example:

Suppose 1000 farmers plant potatoes this season, producing 100,000 tons in a normal year. 
If this is a normal year, when the production is equal to or less than the demand, government need not play any role. 
However, if this is a bumper year and this year's production spikes by 20% to 120,000 tons, FSL will be implemented in four steps:

1. The government sets an MSP for potatoes.
2. It ensures no entity purchases potatoes below MSP.
3. The government procures 20,000 tons of surplus potatoes from farmers at MSP.
4. Each farmer benefits equally. Poor farmers benefit more. 

For instance, every farmer can sell 20 tons of potatoes to the government, ensuring fair treatment.

The outcomes?

1. Farmers' anxieties dissipate, offering immediate relief. Even the smallest farmer benefits fully.
2. The government's financial burden remains manageable, buying only surplus produce.
3. Traders must adhere to MSP, stabilizing market prices and benefiting consumers.

The only losers are the black marketers exploiting farmers.

While FSL won't solve all farmer woes, securing lives and livelihoods paves the way for additional remedies.

Why only 2-3 stateтАЩs farmers wants this and they are protesting currently? Are rest of the Indian farmers ignorants ?

ARGUMENT SUMMARY:
The video argues that Indian farmers deserve a legally guaranteed Minimum Support Price (MSP) based on a comprehensive cost calculation, but the government has failed to provide this.

TRUTH CLAIMS:

CLAIM: Farmers are demanding a legally guaranteed MSP based on the C2+50% cost calculation.

CLAIM SUPPORT EVIDENCE: 
- The Swaminathan Commission reports from 2004-2006 recommended setting MSP at least 50% more than the comprehensive cost of production (C2) [1].
- M.S. Swaminathan, who headed the commission, has reiterated on multiple occasions that MSP should be C2+50% [2].

CLAIM REFUTATION EVIDENCE:
- The government has stated that it already provides MSP that is 50% above the A2+FL cost, a more limited cost calculation [3].
- Some argue that a C2+50% MSP would be fiscally unsustainable and distort markets [4].

LOGICAL FALLACIES:
- Cherry picking: Focuses on the 6% of farmers who benefit from MSP while ignoring the 94% who don't, to argue MSP is currently adequate.

CLAIM RATING: B

LABELS: Pro-farmer, anti-corporate, emotional appeal, oversimplification

CLAIM: The 3 farm laws passed by the Modi government in 2020 favored corporates over farmers.

CLAIM SUPPORT EVIDENCE:
- The farm laws were drafted based on consultations with corporations like Adani and Patanjali, without farmer representation [5]. 
- Provisions allowed corporations to buy, sell and hoard with fewer restrictions than previously [6].
- Private markets were exempt from taxes that government markets had to pay [6].

CLAIM REFUTATION EVIDENCE:
- The government argued the laws would allow farmers more choice of where to sell and lead to modernization of the agriculture sector [7].
- Some farmer groups supported the laws as enabling more free market competition [8].

LOGICAL FALLACIES: 
- Guilt by association: Implying the laws are bad because Gautam Adani, portrayed negatively, would benefit from them.
- False dilemma: Frames it as MSP vs farm laws, ignoring that both could theoretically coexist.

CLAIM RATING: C 

LABELS: Anti-corporate, pro-farmer, reductionist, lacking nuance

OVERALL SCORE:
LOWEST CLAIM SCORE: C
HIGHEST CLAIM SCORE: B  
AVERAGE CLAIM SCORE: B-

OVERALL ANALYSIS:
The video makes an impassioned case for legally guaranteed MSP for farmers but oversimplifies a complex issue. While it provides evidence for farmers' struggles, it lacks nuance in analyzing policy solutions. Viewers should seek more balanced sources to fully understand this multifaceted topic.

Farming is experiencing significant losses, especially during the BJP era. You can verify this by speaking with any farmer. I come from a middle-class farming family in Nashik, Maharashtra, where onions, grapes, and corn are the main crops, all of which are currently unprofitable. The government banned onion exports just before the production time, and grapes are selling for just Rs 20 per kilogram at wholesale rates. Meanwhile, production costs have skyrocketed while prices remain stagnant. Most crops in Maharashtra don't even have Minimum Support Prices (MSP), and it's unclear if the MSP formula is updated in an Excel file. It takes five years for farmers to recover from one year of losses due to the complex economics involved. The ground reality is harsh, as evidenced by farmers sending their children to big cities for low-paying jobs. Despite videos like this, nothing seems likely to change because farmers are not united. Farmers here are earning more than what they were earning earlier, their condition has improved.
Whenever we talk about MSP, it give equal amounts of commodity to every farmer but bro believe me farmers in HARYANA, Punjab and UP WEST are in way better condition than others.

I agreed you , but example give in the end is not logical..If farmes sale for 20 rs per kg (just for example).. The person who will buy from farmer has to pay for shipping , loading , storing and his profit , then it will go to company , most likely company will pay something 30 to 35 rs per kg to this seller, then company has to process the corn , don't forget labor , management , infrastructure , packaging and marketing cost .Now final product will be ready  in the company and cost will be more than 100 rs per kg and now company has to ship to local distributor their commission or profit for storage , transportation and investment, and later on this will go to street vendor , their profit or commission , now will get the corn as consumer. And last when you take i kg of corn , you will not get 1 kg of roosted corn may be 600/700 gram hardly ,, Pl be logical not emotional. its easy to blame middle man , but in the trade without middle man their is no shipping . trading and selling?

MSP ka koyi fyda nahi milta kisaan ko, aur rental farmer koto kuch vi nahi milta. Dalal govt. Officer se  tie up karke kisan ko bolte hai ki govt. Ko fasal bech ney ki kota khatam ho geya hai , fir wo kisan majboori main Local market main bechti hai kam dam main private party ko . Fir private party bohot sare kisan card jugar kar  k unse govt. Ko bech k paisa kamate hai unn khali kota k andar jo farmer ko bataya geya tha ki yeah to khatam ho geye hai . Govt. Should apply digital services  where farmers can see the actual kota not manipulated kota . Aur Bohot sare log hai jinke pass jameen hai par kheti nahi khete nahi karte firvi  kisan card banak baithe hai aur scheme k paisa , equipment lete hai free main govt. Se . 2. Impact on MSP 

Fear has been expressed by the leaders of some farmersтАЩ unions in Punjab and Haryana that the new Act aims to gradually stop public procurement through MSP, which will leave the field open to private corporate players considered a threat to farmers. MSP for wheat and paddy will remain a genuine concern for Punjab and Haryana till better crop options are developed. However, linking the continuation of MSP to the new Act has no grounds whatsoever. MSP and procurement are purely administrative decisions. If the government has the intention to change them, it does not require the help of any act or law. The intentions of the incumbent government regarding MSP and procurement should be better judged from its actions. During the last six years, the current government at the Centre has given three major pushes to the MSP regime. One, a new benchmark for MSP, which ensures 50% or higher margin on cost A2+imputed cost of family labour. As a result of which, MSP has moved up to a higher trajectory. Two, much-needed procurement for ensuring MSP expanded to some other crops. To support this, the Centre is now maintaining a bu er stock of pulses. Three, a new scheme, ASHA, was started to extend financial support and share cost/losses to states that pay MSP to farmers for pulses. These moves show the commitment of the Central government towards MSP. Some estimates suggest that MSP reaches less than 7% of farmers in the country. This is in sync with other evidence that shows the share of officially procured crop output close to 11% in total crop output, and 7% in total agricultural output. This raises the challenge to ensure remunerative prices for the remaining 90% of produce. The underlying intention of the new Act has been to keep the MSP system intact for the produce already benefiting 12from it and create a policy environment that improves price realization for the remaining produce. Suggestions have been made to make MSP a statutory price for producers and treat any transaction below it as unlawful. If according legal status will ensure MSP to farmers, then this would be the easiest way for any government to help farmers get desired prices. This can be done by state governments and does not require Central intervention. Kerala has announced minimum prices for 16 fruit and vegetables on 27 October. Economic theory as well experience indicate that the price level that is not supported by demand and supply cannot be sustained through legal means. This was tried by Maharashtra in 2018 when the Cabinet approved a change in law to send any trader to jail for a year and impose a penalty of Rs 50,000 for not adhering to MSP declared by the government. As open market prices were lower than the (legalized) MSP levels declared by the state, the buyers withdrew from market and farmers had to su er. The move was soon abandoned. Another example is that of sugarcane, where MSP (fair and remunerative price) is statutory minimum price. When sugar mills (private sector) did not find FRP for sugarcane matching with sugar prices, they stopped buying and crushing sugarcane. A long, protracted battle in court could not o er a solution. Finally, sugar mills were no longer making full payments to sugarcane producers, resulting in the accumulation of arrears running into thousands of crores of rupees every year. On the other side, the new trading Act creates a favourable environment for private buyers to pay MSP as it saves APMC fee, user charges, commission charges and many other costs. This also shows that any move by the states to counter a Central act while keeping market fee, user charges, commissions, cess, etc., intact, will in practice work against private traders giving MSP to farmers by making purchase price costlier. The new Act has also been criticized by quoting the example of Bihar, which scrapped the APMC Act in 2006. It is argued that freeing trade in Bihar did not help in getting MSPтАУтАУhowever, they were not getting MSP even before the scrapping of the APMC Act! Price data from Bihar shows that average farm harvest price for ten years before the scrapping of the APMC Act was 30% below MSP, which went down to 20% in the following decade. This does not indicate any negative e ect on prices received by farmers due to scrapping of the APMC Act. The second, and more serious, flaw in this argument is that the FPTC Act is taken to imply the shutting down of APMC 13markets. The major di erence between what Bihar did and what is proposed in the FPTC Act 2020 is to create one more option for farmers while retaining the option of selling produce in APMC mandis. As discussed earlier, the best benefit from the new Act will accrue when APMC mandis and private channels coexist and compete. This can be ensured by the states by nurturing APMC mandis as infrastructure service for the farmersтАУтАУlike other government facilities such as hospitals, schools, roads and parks, etc.тАУтАУrather than using them for generating revenue for the government and middlemen. It is also pertinent to point out that the mere existence of APMC markets does not ensure MSP, as seen in the case of many crops in Punjab and Haryana and with wheat and paddy in several states. There are also cases of sizable procurement at MSP in states without the APMC Act (20 lakh tons of paddy procured in Bihar and 7 lakh tons in Kerala in 2019тАУ20). Implementation and continuation of MSP is an administrative decision and in the case of rice and wheat it is part of the four pillars of food security, that include (i) procurement, (ii) bu er stock and (iii) PDS in addition to MSP. The system will collapse if one pillar is demolished. No responsible government would like to be seen as doing damage to the system that has served the purpose of food security, price stability, food self-su ciency so well. The Prime Minister has stated a couple of times that the MSP system will continue after implementation of the new farm acts. The Union Agriculture Minister has even given written assurance in this regard. It is very clear that the running MSP system has nothing to do with the APMC Act or FPTC Act 2020.

I decided to dig deep into the subject after watching your video. I haven't seen your video on 3 farm laws, their introduction and abolition. From the information available on Niti Ayog website, it was meant to safeguard farmers from the middlemen. For viewers of your channel, I am copy-pasting some points from the pdf available on 3 farm laws of 2020.

1. FarmersтАЩ Produce Trade and Commerce (Promotion and Facilitation) Act 2020 (FPTC Act) 

The FPTC Act, enacted by the Central government, gives the freedom to sell and buy farm produce at any place in the countryтАУтАУwithin APMC mandis or outside them. To promote e-commerce in agriculture, the new law also allows the setting up of an electronic platform for the sale and/or purchase of farm produce. The Act also has a provision to prescribe modalities for the registration of traders and trade transactions in trade areas. Thus, if the new system does not work satisfactorily, then the government can intervene to regulate the system. Due to inadequacies of the APMC markets, more than half of the marketable surplus is sold outside the mandis. Such deals lack transparency and fairness as they are in violation of APMC regulation; due to their underhanded nature, there is also the constant fear of being busted upon by APMC o cials. The new Act legalizes such transactions, which is favourable for farmers. The best part of the new Act is that it allows direct purchase from farmers at their doorstep or farm, as is the case with milk. For the first time, farmers will have the opportunity to quote the price for their produce. Although these changes might appear too good to be true, if reforms are encouraged in the right direction by the states, it wonтАЩt take long for farmer producers or their FPOs to become тАЬprice dictatorsтАЭ rather than remaining тАЬprice takersтАЭ. 08Another relevant question is how smallholders will benefit from the new Act. Our farm size is getting smaller day by day. If we want our farmers to diversify to produce high-value crops, they need price assurance and outlet to sell small lots. Crops like fresh vegetables and fruit do not mature on the same day and are thus harvested in small lots over time. This requires a collection facility or sale opportunity near the farm as is the case with dairy production throughout the country. FPTC will facilitate the creation of the required ecosystem for diversification at small farms. Traditional supply chains involve six to seven transactions between the production point and end use (farm to fork). Each transaction involves cost and margin, leading to a large price spread between producers and consumers. FPTC will result in compressing the value chains and eliminating excessive intermediation. In many cases farmers will be able to sell their produce directly to consumers through their groups. The new policy environment will create business opportunities for the rural youth, including farmersтАЩ children, in agriculture trading, as witnessed in denotified crops and the dairy sector.

Simplify technical terms: Instead of using complex terms like "economy," you could say "how money and jobs work" or "how we manage our resources." Similarly, "cost" could be replaced with "price" or "how much something costs," and "account" could be replaced with "keeping track of money."
